intro: Sieglingia texana, commonly known as the Texas Sieglingia, is a rare flowering plant native to the central and eastern regions of Texas. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in open, sandy soils along stream banks and in woodland edges. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers clustered in racemes, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a slight pubescence, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, Sieglingia texana is considered a species of conservation concern.
